p.s: Boris Johnson tries to convince his audience at the summit of the necessity to combat climate change by starting to act now by drawing their attention to the impatient people waiting for ana solution, therefore he uses different rethoricalrhetorical devices.
Boris Johnson introduces his speech with a comparison of the climate crisis and a James Bond action movie.
In this way he evokes interest and curiosity of the audience because they wonder why he starts talking about a fictional character.
He also uses a metaphor to present his idea by calling James Bond the fictional son of Scotland (l. 2).
In this way and also through inclusive language he achieves that the listener pays attention.

The use of the pronoun we (l. 6, 9, 10...) symbolizes that everyone is in the same situation and they have to find a solution together by comparing the climate change with a doomsday device (l. 5) he illustrates the danger of disaster.
He also mentions the clock that is ticking down (l. 4f.) which creates a pressure on the audience to do something before it is totoo late.
Because James Bond is a detail of common knowledge we can talk of ana allusion right here that puts the events into graphic accounts.
Johnson admits that the governments have made mistakes in the past and didn't get real on their promises made in Copenhagen or Paris.
He uses colloquial language by repeating the past discussion with blah, blah, blah (l. 13) to show the nonsense.
This earns him sympathy of the audience and at the same time he makes new promises and gives his listeners hope that this is the point of time when tthings get real (l. 15).
The ellipsis And we can (l. 16) in the following paragraph supports the given feeling of hope.
To name some concrete examples he ennumeratesenumerates area where things should be changed as soon as possible (l. 16).
Then he refers to the comparison from the beginning that accompanies the listener as a leading motive through the holewhole speech and creates a frame and certain structure.

Johnson kind of blames the others for the raising temperatures by not including himself when it comes to the creation of the problem (l. 19) and saying that the UK already has reached its goal and now it is the turn of the rest of the world (l. 28).
But at the same time he claims that all nations have to work together in order to reach the goal.
The climax hundreds of billions to hundreds of trillions (l. 23) show that this is the only way to really see remarkable results.
He repeats that humanity has the technologies for this change (l. 30/l. 16) and now it depends on the will.
He tries to convince the audience to think about the fact that even if they don't have that long time left on earth there are others that live way longer or are not even born yet.
These are the people that expect policies to take action and the COP26 representivesrepresentatives have to respect the future generations.
With a methaphormetaphor refuring to theater (l. 40) he states that that is the reason why there can not be any empty words and promises anymore.
Again he gives his audience hope by talking about Glasgow as a turning point and failure is an unexcaptableunexpectable outcome of the COP26 summit.
He repeat that they have the necessary funds by ennumeratingenumerating the possibilatiespossibilities they have.
He stresses his thesis by the use of an anapheranaphora (l. 46-47).

Finally he comes back to the James Bond comparison and shows the audience that even if now it is hard to imagine that the battle can be won mankind can combat climate change if we work together and see COP26 as a turning point.
This gets underlined by the alliteration to turn the tide (l. 51).
Especially the last two sentences encouragesencourage the audience one last time to take action.
Even if it is a great challangechallenge we can do it just like James Bond in all his movies.
To come to a conclusion we can say that Boris Johnson convinces his audience to take action right now and do not lose the hope of winning the battle against climate change.
Therefore he uses a comparison throughout his whole speech that illustrates climate change with an action movie.
Through this structure and the use of stylistic devices just like inclusive language he gives the audience hope.
